com.viaoa.jfc.editor.html

Class OAHTMLTextPane

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • javax.swing.JComponent

            • javax.swing.JEditorPane
              • javax.swing.JTextPane
                • com.viaoa.jfc.editor.html.OAHTMLTextPane
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    OAPrintable, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.awt.print.Printable, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.Scrollable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    OAHTMLTextPaneFooter, OAHTMLTextPaneHeader

    public class OAHTMLTextPane
extends javax.swing.JTextPane
implements OAPrintable
    Text pane used for html styled editor. Subclasses JTextPane and adds support for pasting and printing:
    • setBase can be used to set base location to a jar file url.
    • Pasting will clean up html to make it compatible.
    • Printing pages, managing page breaks
    Links: http://java-sl.com/articles.html http://java-sl.com/tips.html http://java-sl.com/tips.html todo: replace smiles with image Note: sizes are based on pixels. If point sizes were used in HTML, then they are converted to pixel size. Java font sizes are based on pixel, printer font sizes are based on point.
    From Font.getSize(): "The Java(tm)2D API adopts the convention that one point is equivalent to one unit in user coordinates" When printing, the graphics is scaled using the printer/screen dpi settings. For printing, the printer resolution is based on points, 72/inch. Screen dpi can vary, common is 96 (windows).

    IMPORTANT: need to convert from point to pixel whenever using PageFormat or Paper. For printing, graphics.scale(x,x) is set to make it wysiwyg

    !!! Important !!!! this is from javax.swing.text.html.CSS.java http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/swing/text/html/CSS.html Defines a set of CSS attributes as a typesafe enumeration. The HTML View implementations use CSS attributes to determine how they will render. This also defines methods to map between CSS/HTML/StyleConstants. Any shorthand properties, such as font, are mapped to the intrinsic properties.

    The following describes the CSS properties that are supported by the rendering engine: see: javax.swing.text.html.CSS.java for sizes, values default to "px"

    • font-family
    • font-style
    • font-size (supports relative units)
    • font-weight (450, normal, bold, etc)
    • font
    • color
    • background-color (with the exception of transparent)
    • background-image ex: style="background-image: url('oaproperty://com.tmgsc.hifive.model.oa.ImageStore/Bytes?3');"
    • background-repeat ex: background-repeat: no-repeat;repeat,no-repeat,repeat-y,repeat-x
    • background-position
    • background ???? verify that this is correct qqqqqqqqqqq
    • width
    • height
    • text-decoration ex: underline, overline, not: overline,blink
    • vertical-align (only sup and super)
    • text-align left, center, right, justify=center
    • margin
    • margin-top
    • margin-right
    • margin-bottom
    • margin-left
    • padding
    • padding-top
    • padding-right
    • padding-bottom
    • padding-left
    • border-style (supports inset, outset, none, solid)
    • border-width (only supports one size for all sides)
    • border-color -top, -right, -bottom, -left ** NOTE ** for , if the Border attr is used, then it's value will be used for all TD border-width, for any TD inside of it (even inner tables) set Table attribute "BORDER=0" to remove lines
    • list-style-type
    • list-style-position The following are modeled, but currently not rendered.
      • font-variant
      • background-attachment (background always treated as scroll)
      • word-spacing
      • letter-spacing
      • text-indent
      • text-transform
      • line-height
      • border-top-width (this is used to indicate if a border should be used)
      • border-right-width
      • border-bottom-width
      • border-left-width
      • border-width
      • border-top
      • border-right
      • border-bottom
      • border-left
      • border
      • width
      • height
      • float
      • clear
      • display
      • white-space
      • list-style

      Note: for the time being we do not fully support relative units, unless noted, so that p { margin-top: 10% } will be treated as if no margin-top was specified. ******* Tags/Attributes added by OA *******

      division block used where page breaks should not occur
      used to force a page break before
      • table row that should be repeated if table is multiple pages Example: OAHTMLTextPane txt = tabExamVisit.getNoteHTMLTextPane(); OAHTMLTextPaneController contEditor = new OAHTMLTextPaneController(txt, SpellCheckDelegate.getSpellChecker(), true); contEditor.bind(model.getExams(), Exam.P_Note); contEditor.createImageHandler(model.getExamImageStores(), ImageStore.P_Bytes, ImageStore.P_OrigFileName, ImageStore.P_Id); // or: contEditor.createFileImageHandler(); contEditor.setEnabled(model.getUserAccess(), UserAccess.P_ExamEnabled); OAScroller scroller = new OAScroller(contEditor.getToolBar()); tabExamVisit.getNotesPanel().add(scroller, BorderLayout.NORTH);
      Author:
      vvia
      See Also:
      for binding, added features, usage and sample, Serialized Form

      • getPrintSize

        public java.awt.Dimension getPrintSize(int pageIndex,
                              java.awt.print.PageFormat pageFormat,
                              int width)
        Description copied from interface: OAPrintable
        Used to know the size of a page. This is used for reports that have multiple printables per page, usually when using a header and footer. Note: This could be called before the page is actually printed. In most cases, this will return the total size of the printable.
        Specified by:
        getPrintSize in interface OAPrintable
        pageFormat - which has sizes in points - (which might need to be converted to pixels, for comparisons)
        width - is in pixels

      • getImage

        public java.awt.Image getImage(java.lang.String name,
                      java.net.URL url)
        This is called from the MyImageView to get an image associated with an image tag. It will first use the image cache, and if not found will call loadImage.
        See Also:
        loadImage(String, URL)

      • loadImage

        protected java.awt.Image loadImage(java.lang.String name,
                       java.net.URL url)
        Called by getImage. This will call imageHandler first. This method can be used as a hook, so that an application can retrieve images that are used in a document.

      • getFieldClass

        public java.lang.Class getFieldClass()
        Get the class to use for the list of Fields that a user can insert into a document. If fieldClass was not set by calling setFieldClass(..), then it will look for a method named "get"+propertyPath+"FieldClass" from the current Hub's class. If not found then it will use the Hub's class.
        Returns:

      • getController

      • createImageHandler

        public void createImageHandler(Hub<?> hub,
                      java.lang.String byteArrayPropertyName,
                      java.lang.String sourceNamePropertyName,
                      java.lang.String idPropertyName)
        Parameters:
        hub - Hub that has all images in it.
        byteArrayPropertyName - name of property that is for a byte[] to store "raw"
        sourceNamePropertyName - property to use to store the source of the image (ex: file name)
        idPropertyName - unique property value to use for the html img src tag. If null, then sourceNamePropertyName will be used.
        See Also:
        Hub2ImageHandler

      • createImageHandler

        public void createImageHandler(java.lang.Class<? extends OAObject> clazz,
                      java.lang.String byteArrayPropertyName,
                      java.lang.String sourceNamePropertyName,
                      java.lang.String idPropertyName)
